description: Lenart Kova intervenes to override the automated purge, risking retaliation from Council hardliners. His decision preserves the entire archive of BCI logs and surveillance data.
Word quickly spreads through Stenograd that the city's digital memory—evidence of injustice as well as routine life—has been saved at the last moment. Relief and anxiety mix in the population.
Harmonists urge that essential services be restored everywhere, but require that protest districts commit to citywide negotiations over the future of the BCI system.

In response, Halden Zone assemblies draft and broadcast a 'reverse oath,' demanding public accountability for past BCI abuses and the right to debate the system’s dismantling. Public forums and mass gatherings begin citywide.

During live-streamed negotiations, a previously suppressed recording from Halden emerges, warning about the dangers of automated control. The revelation intensifies calls for transparent justice, leading the Council to consider a citywide, binding vote on Stenograd’s future.
